keen.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: wanting to do something or wanting something to happen very much
keen.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: He told me that he was keen to help.
I wasn’t keen on going there on my own.
The government is keen for peace talks to start again.
The chairman is keen that the company should expand its product range.
keen.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: someone who is keen on something is very interested in it or enjoys doing it very much
keen.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: She takes a keen interest in politics and current affairs.
I was mad keen on dinosaurs when I was little.
keen.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: someone who is keen is eager to work or learn, and enjoys doing it
keen.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: The kids in my class are all very keen.
She was new in the job and keen as mustard  (=very keen).
keen.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: a keen sense of smell or keen sight or hearing is an extremely good ability to smell etc
keen.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: Dogs have a very keen sense of smell.
She has a keen eye for  (=is good at noticing) talent.
keen.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: someone with a keen mind is quick to understand things
keen.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: With her keen mind and good business sense, she soon became noticed.
keen.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: a keen feeling is one that is strong and deep
keen.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: As she walked away, Joe felt a keen sense of loss.
keen.translation[0].definitions[6].defin: used to describe a situation in which people compete strongly
keen.translation[0].definitions[6].examp: We won the contest in the face of keen competition.
keen.translation[0].definitions[7].defin: a keen knife or blade is extremely sharp
keen.translation[0].definitions[8].defin: a keen wind is cold and strong
keen.translation[0].note_box[0].items[0]: You are keen on something or keen on doing something
We’re all very keen on sports
We’re all very keen of sports
keen.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: to sing a loud sad song for someone who has died
keen.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: if competition is keen, people are trying very hard to get an advantage over others doing the same thing
keen.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: Business has become scarcer, competition keener and profit margins slimmer.
These properties are likely to attractkeen bidding in a buoyant property market.
keen.translation[2].definitions[1].defin: keen prices, rates etc are low when compared to competitors’ prices etc
keen.translation[2].definitions[1].examp: London’s present system provideskeen prices for actively traded stocks.
the opportunity to achieve the keenest interest rates
keen.translation[2].definitions[2].defin: if someone is keen, they are very eager or interested in doing something
keen.translation[2].definitions[2].examp: Investors already have shown keen interest in the $100 million issue.
Japanese investors are keen on obtaining more foreign assets.
The Swiss group is said to be keen to buy a stake in the company.
